rComments: I took Prof. Bernier'sCapstone seminar on Policy Instruments after previously taking his course on Democratic Governance and Public Policy. Although I found the workload to be overwhelming at times, he always made himself available to answer any questions we may have about our assignments. His courses just require a little more effort than others.

Try your best to avoid him. Doesn't give you marks until the end of the semester, is rude with his comments about the public service and in grading (I'm all for constructive criticism, but he shame's/bully's students). Course material was also about 5 years old and needs a refresh. I'll have PTSD for life.

He was okay; seems like a nice guy and has good sense of humour. Unfortunately the class was very dry and the lectures were basically useless. His grading criteria is very vague, his feedback is useless and marks more harshly but not unfair. I would avoid if possible but he may be is better in person.

I took Democratic Government and Public Policy with Professor Bernier in French. His assignments were really enjoyable, which included group advocacy brief. His lectures were funny (his jokes make more sense in french than in English) even though they could also be dry at times. He is also a fair marker and cares about his students.

Suffering through his Case Studies course. There is nothing wrong with the material and you have to write two papers each week. BUT, this man cannot speak English and he's teaching an English course. On top of this he tries to tell jokes in broken English and takes 30 mins to tell his boring stories. Sitting through his class is torture.
